The Seed wouldn't be here if it weren't for the community. This idea came to fruition through the help of donations from the community and those donations have made it possible for us to serve the space (and the food) back to you :)

column1: <h2 style=""color: #008000
","The Seed is downtown Lancaster's ONLY community space and vegan/vegetarian cafe.
We are also a worker-owned collective that is trying to inspire people to change the world!
As many of you know, our Mission is:
To provide local, sustainably sourced food and beverage in an open, safe space for Lancaster's progressive community
column2: a place to gather and continue the work of social justice, community-building and service to each other and the planet.

column1: We have an opportunity to expand our space and make it better so the people of Lancaster (and beyond!) have more room for community-building, healthier food/beverage options and more! The Seed wouldn't be here if it weren't for the community. This idea came to fruition through the help of donations from the community and those donations have made it possible for us to serve the space (and the food) back to you :)

If we raise enough money, we can create ""the people's classroom"", where more activists, environmental groups, holistic health care providers, and others can meet and do the work we intended The Seed to do when it was first conceived.  We can also improve our food service capabilities, and expand our lending library, as well as provide Gallery Space to showcase the unique work of artists and craft makers.
It's time for us to take the opportunity to make this unique space bigger and better and we need your help!

The Community approaches The Seed everyday with suggestions and amazing ideas. We thrive on this kind of support and want to see as many possibilities come to fruition as we can. Our goal is to raise $15,000 so we can expand into a bigger space and make all of your suggestions a reality.
The suggestions you gave us were:
-Better lighting
-A working website with menu (duh!)
-Organic, vegan smoothies
-An advanced system for filtering drinking water.
-More fermented brewing options + more Kombucha + more herbal Kombucha flavors
-Expanded lending library
-More space for private meetings/events/workshops (away from the cafe noise) + a people's classroom (with a large chalkboard and a copier for people to use)
-Stage lighting for our stage to help out local musicians and artists
- Improved Signs so people can find us

- We are also hoping to improve our commercial kitchen equipment, and increase cold storage space for the growing demand on our supply. We need a new refrigerator, freezer, and bigger panini press to hold and prepare our food orders.
If we make the $15,000 goal, we can make ALL of this happen.

For those of you who love The Seed for the food, the events, the chance to engage in an open, safe space, or all of these things, we ask for your support. We are a worker owned and operated business, and we see no profit from the sale of our products. Everything we earn in the cafe goes back into creating a vibrant space to learn and grow as a community.
If each one of our fans on facebook donates JUST $10, we will reach our goal! Let’s DO THIS!

We know we can't just ask for $15,000 and not give you back some awesome perks.  We thought we'd run our campaign with the community, so the perks are even more exciting than anything The seedlings could give by themselves!
We put most of our perks into what we call “Artisan Perk Packages” which means at least one local artist has added something super cool to that package.
These are also LIMITED EDITION packages, so grab em' as quickly as you can! We only have so many of each awesome Perk package.
Many of these perks have never been offered to the public like this before!
*Just a peek at some of our artisan goods included in packages*
(Here's an example of one of our professional Vegan 3-tier Cakes - made for any occasion!!)
1. Share this campaign with everyone you know.
(Every $1 Matters!!!!)
2. Come to The Seed and volunteer to hand-out our Indiegogo campaign mini-flyers to the people of Lancaster! Or just come volunteer at The Seed!
3. Post this campaign on blogs + other like-minded sites! We’re all in this together.
4. Keep being you. We like you.
Woot!",7.0,0,"4 Campaigns
|","Lancaster, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/help-the-seed-grow/pica

Transform the Community. Change Lives.

Concerts For Kids is a Denver-based non-profit that raises funds for, and awareness of, local children's charities. Our mission is to enrich the lives of children by providing access to the best healthcare and education available. Through both monetary and in-kind donations, we strive to help children faced with life-threatening illnesses live better lives and to provide all students with the opportunity to participate in educational programs in a safe environment that will help them grow.

Every year, Concerts For Kids coordinates multiple community service projects to better enrich our surroundings. Community Day is the largest of these projects
column2:
nearly 1,000 volunteers are dispersed to over 50 non-profits within the Denver Metro Area to complete facility improvement projects, including painting, landscaping, cleaning, roofing, carpeting and much more. Concerts For Kids provides all materials and supplies needed to complete the project, as well as any professional labor services that may be needed. 

Providing these services allows non-profits the freedom to allocate their staffing and budget dollars toward better serving their mission and the community.

*The Denver Day of Rock is Concerts For Kids' annual five stage, 25-band free concert across the 16th Street Mall in downtown Denver. The event serves not only as a major fundraiser, but is also a vehicle for raising awareness about Concerts For Kids and our beneficiaries. Learn more about Denver Day of Rock here.

What You Can Do

Concerts For Kids relies heavily on our donors to ensure the success of Community Day projects.

To make Community Day possible, we need your help to purchase the supplies needed to transform over 50 non-profit sites. To give you a sense of our costs:

column1: <li>
$5 = (3) 32 oz. spray bottles, used for general cleaning and site maintenance
<li>
$10 = (2) bags of potting soil, to rejuvenate gardens from harsh winters
<li>
$35 = (50) 1 gallon nursery pots, for garden and landscaping needs
<li>
$60 = (30) pairs of work gloves, worn by almost all volunteers
<li>

$100 = (1) landscaping package: (1) stainless steel brush, (1) 32 oz. spray bottle, (1) bottle rust remover, (1) wood transfer shovel, (1) round point shovel, (2) hand towels, (1) square landscaping fabric, (1) flat Early Girl Tomatoes, (1) flat Yellow Crookneck Squash, (1) flat Petunias
<li>
$325 = (1) gardening package: (2) garden benches, (1) flat Rose Security Bushes, (5) paintbrushes, (2) 6' step ladders, (1) power washer rental
Your Impact
column2: >In 2013, Community Day's total value of labor, supplies and monetary giving came to $519,888.41
column3:
>and benefited 767,942 children and families in the Denver community. We strive to grow Community Day each year both in the number of sites served and the total amount given back and need your help to do this.

Other Ways You Can Help

No donation is too small or too large. Every little bit helps!

If you cannot give at this time, please help us spread the word about Concerts For Kids and Community Day.

column1: • Share this page on Facebook
• Tweet us @ConcertsForKids
• Send this campaign to your friends and family members

Thank you to everyone that did contribute, Unfortunately Googly was not able to achieve greatness this time. 



So what's it all about? (the stubby version)
My name is Remo Wakeford and from a very young age I’ve taken great pleasure in being creative.  This project is part of that creativity and has subsequently become somewhat of an obsession with me.

I’ve been a Graphic Designer for about 8 years and 4 years ago I obtained a degree in Industrial Design.  During my student days, the Googly Egg Timer concept popped into my head and has never gone away, now the time has come to develop it further.

It's time that Googly joins other kitchen friends and becomes a range, a range of fun loving and brilliantly inspiring accessories for your kitchen!  Accessories like egg cups, salad spoons, bottle openers, ice trays and even dry food containers. Whether you have kids or not, the Googly Egg Timer will find a place in your heart and your home.
The reason I've come here is to make the Googly timer concept a reality.
That’s where you come in!
I would just love to see Googly on store shelves and know that people are enjoying his happy face in their homes. Help me bring his cuteness into your life by contributing what you can to his birth.
<strong><span style=""font-size: 1.17em

I've been approached by an investor who is very keen on the Googly concept BUT they have requested that I generate more than a single item, rather a range of kitchen accessories like the ones I mentioned above.  The reasoning is that an entire range of products will be more acceptable to the market.

So, in order for Googly to exist, I need to be able to develop and make prototypes of his friends and family (as I think of them) as an integrated group of products. This requires financial resources that I don’t have available, for example, Googly himself cost €300.00 to prototype, that’s without any finishing, polishing or painting.
So, in order to make another 4 buddies it's going to take at least €1200.00 before finishing, add the finishing and I estimate a total cost of about €3500.00.

A portion of the funds will go towards a prototyping budget, paying for the parts, the time and the finishing of each of the buddies, while the balance will go towards the exciting rewards that you, as a special founder member of the Googly club, will get.
<strong><span style=""font-size: 1.17em
column2: >What being part of the Googly club means!

column1: Being in the Googly club is an exclusive accomplishment reserved for those of you that really want to brighten up your lives!
At each level of investment in the Googly project you get different club perks all of which are truly awesome. Although to be fair, those that give more will receive a bit more “awesomeness”.
When you contribute €5.00 you become a copper member of the Googly Club which entitles you to a special mention in the “Googly Founding Fathers” page on the soon to be Googly website.

When you contribute €15.00 you become a bronze member of the Googly Club which entitles you to a special mention in the “Googly Founding Fathers” page on the website and not only that, you will receive a postcard of the Googly Signed by me, the original designer.

When you contribute €50.00 you become a silver member of the Googly Club which entitles you to a special mention in the “Googly Founding Fathers” page on the website, a postcard of the Googly Signed by me, the original designer and along with that awesomeness you also get a limited edition Googly keyring made using the latest rapid prototyping techniques and hand finished by me the designer.

When you contribute €100.00 you become a gold member of the Googly Club which entitles you to a special mention in the “Googly Founding Fathers” page on the website and that's not all!!!! You also get a limited edition book featuring all the original sketches and concept development artwork, signed by me, the original designer.

When you contribute €500.00 you become a platinum member of the Googly Club which entitles you to a special mention in the “Googly Founding Fathers” page on the website and along with your addition to the list of awesome people, Googly will cross your palm with a limited edition stainless steel keyring made by using some of the latest rapid prototyping techniques.  But wait there's more! With this investment comes an exclusive and once in a lifetime opportunity to get your hands on a prototype Googly, in its packaging and supplied with a certificate of authenticity! This googly is hand finished by me the original designer.

If you're as passionate as me about this project and you contribute €1000.00 or more, you become a diamond member of the Googly Club and to separate you from everyone else you not only get your hands on a prototype Googly but you get to choose whether you want the standard purple and green Googly or the more classic black and red version which also comes in its packaging with a certificate of authenticity! This googly is hand finished by me the original designer. And you also get to add a signed copy of the limited edition book featuring all the original sketches and concept development artwork as well as the limited edition stainless steel keyring to add to your collection of awesome things.
<strong><span style=""font-size: 1.17em
column2: >So what happens if Googly doesn't make it?

column1: If Googly doesn't make it?! well lets hope that doesn't happen! But if it does I'll do what I can to give what's been promised. After that I'll just have to go back to polishing shoes on the streets of Dublin to generate some extra cash, so that Googly can be born.
<span style=""font-size: 1.17em

This project is something that is not only close to my heart but something I believe will help generate a new accessory company with a fresh flavor that has a similar design philosophy to Alessi, the post-modern, high design, Italian kitchen utensil company.   Not only that but a design firm that can give back to society by generating affordable, fun and functional designer products.

If you can't contribute right now thats ok, just make sure you tell your friends, family, colleagues, aquaintances, ex's, teachers, lecturers, local police, the post office and literally anyone you can about this project. I've included a little card below that you can print out and give to people so that they can check it out. Also Indiegogo has many sharing tools that you can use to let your social network buddies find out about the awesome Googly.
Oh and before I sign off, Googly thanks you! from the bottom of his soon to be real heart!

Oceanside Candles is celebrating its product launch!  From September 16th until October 31st, 2013, we are offering discounted prices on our Holiday Fragrance line of Large Jar Candles:
<ul>
• Oceanside Candles are handmade in the USA
• Our candles are triple-scented for maximum fragrance
• Our large jars are larger and burn longer than the leading national brand.
Plus, if you make a purchase by September 30th, you can take advantage of our EARLY BIRD DISCOUNT DEALS and enjoy even deeper discounts!
Why we need your support
Within the next 45 Days, our goal is to raise $10,000.  Your purchases will help us to:
<ul>
• Purchase equipment and supplies
• Launch our full product line in January 2014
• Expand our product availabiltiy to Amazon.com and retail venues
What it means to us
By purchasing one of the available packages, you are helping us to fulfill our goal. To show our appreciation, we offer you the following:
<ul>
• This One-time-only opportunity to enjoy lifetime employee pricing ($10 package)
• Our 2013 Holiday Fragrance Collection at wholesale pricing
<li>Preferred customer status - Shop future Clearance &amp
column2: Sale items before they are available to the general public

column1: Other Ways You Can Help
While we appreciate your financial support, we understand if you cannot make a purchase at this time.  We would appreciate you showing your support in the following ways:
<ul>
• Use the share tools to let your friends and family know about our campaign
• Visit our website at Oceansidecandles.com and join our mailing list

Thank you for your support!!!

Our 2013 Holiday Fragrance Collection at wholesale pricing
Preferred customer status - Shop future Clearance & Sale items before they are available to the general public
Other Ways You Can Help
While we appreciate your financial support, we understand if you cannot make a purchase at this time.  We would appreciate you showing your support in the following ways:
Use the share tools to let your friends and family know about our campaign
Visit our website at Oceansidecandles.com and join our mailing list
Thank you for your support!!!",1.0,0,"1 Campaign

A better picture is on the way, maybe even a video.

http://treatstreetbicycle.com/

My name is Ben Smith and I operate Treat Street Bicycle Works.  Treat Street is a very, very small independent bike shop on the edge of the Mission District in San Francisco.  The shop currently has the opportunity to expand in all the right ways.  This larger space is going to allow us to serve our community better and faster while creating more jobs.

I started Treat Street 2 ½ years ago with my bike tools and a month’s rent.  I had been unemployed for about a year and was making ends meet by setting up my stand in the park on weekends and working for tips.  A friend gave me a heads up on an inexpensive space and Treat Street Bicycle Works started with 133 sq. ft.  The community responded quickly and I was able to move into a larger space within 6 months.  The shop currently operates with one bench with a dual stand in a space that is less than 230 sq. ft.  To say it’s a tight, is an understatement.

Community Based Business

Treat Street has become an important resource to the community.  Our main customer base is comprised of commuters and people who live on their bikes.  We work on all bikes and pride ourselves in providing same-day/next-day service often with on-the-spot return.  

Treat Street has recently joined the San Francisco Bicycle Coalition's discount partner program.  We have also become the pre-ride bike service for San Francisco Bike Party, a monthly law-abiding mass bike ride.  We are also heavily involved with the San Francisco Bike Polo League and are the service center for many of our players.

Jobs

For the first year, it was just me.  All my time and every dime went into the shop.  Last summer I had 3 part time employees and was able to keep one on over the winter.  I have trained three mechanics from scratch, two of whom still work full time with their new trade.

Right now the vision is to bring on 2 full time mechanics and a part-timer or two.  It would also be nice to have someone aid with inventory and bookkeeping.  We are looking to hire people with a passion for mechanics and the love of bike life.  

We have great reviews, a loyal customer base, and truly love working for our neighborhood.  From the moment you walk into the shop, our passion for bikes and commitment to community is apparent.

Our Expansion Needs

The expansion goal is to add two more benches, two more double stands, a wheel station, and inventory storage.  The new space is going to add over 680 sq ft.: And that is just the floor.  We work vertically, we will be hanging bikes and wheels off the ceiling.  We will need a lot of ceiling hooks.  All of the hooks, workbenches and storage will need to be built in place.

$12K is the main goal.  This allows for:

INSTALLATION:
Benches
Shelves
Computer
Display Wall
Bike, wheel and tire hooks and racks
Security
Phone

TOOLS
Bench tools ($4k)
2 double work stands($1.2)
1 truing stand


INVENTORY
Parts and accessories to handle increased volume.
New bikes
Helmet stock (We did not have the space to stock before)


The dream goal is to get at least twice that.  Excess funds will go towards immediate installation, staffing and the possibility of bringing in a bike line.

Gifts To The Givers
<ul>
• Invite to Thank You party at the new space (est. June 28th)
• Treat Street Bicycle Works ""Ride Happy"" button
• Custom designed Treat Street Bicycle Works T-Shirt
• Extreme discounts on Tune Ups
• $450 gets $500 labor credit
• $1111 bike labor for 2 years or $1111 labor credit donation
• If you do not live in the immediate area, you can donate your service dollars to one of several local charities. (SFBC, Y-Bike, Wheelie Kids, Urban Riders, others)

If we do not meet the goal every little bit will help.  In the event of not reaching the goal, I will work that much harder to make it happen.  I am committed to the idea and intend on going forward.  It will just take a lot longer to outfit the shop and set up the new space.  It will also be a lot more difficult to bring on new people right away.  


Other Ways You Can Help

Just because you cannot contribute, does not mean you can’t help:
<ul>
• Please, please, please spread the word.  Facebook, twitter and other social media outlets are easy to share.
• Forward this info to anyone with a bike or cares about bikes
• Email those who may be interested our plight.
• Indiegogo has several share tools to make it easy to let others know.

Thank you for considering aiding in the expansion of Treat Street Bicycle Works.  Your contributions will go towards making a difference in the cycling community, creating jobs and keeping independent local business alive.

2.62mile Common Man's ""Marathon""

Sunday, April 29th: 8am Registration, 9am Start
Boston Common, Northwest corner
Our Story

A couple of years ago, we chartered a new Rotary Club for Downtown Boston. We are passionate about SERVICE ABOVE SELF to make positive, lasting changes. We all care about different kinds of service and play to our strengths. Some of us focus on community service
column2: some of us help our new club grow
column3: some of us serve through our vocations
column4: some will pilot international service through the Futurevision program.

column1: Now, WE NEED YOUR HELP with the 2nd annual Common Man's ""Marathon,"" a 2.62 mile race around the Boston Common. ALL funds from registration fees and sponsorship go to community service projects for local urban youth. We need volunteers to serve as course marshalls --please send us a ""Comment"" on this site, if you can help
column2: we'll get in touch with you. Each Rotary Club is self-sufficient and does its own work on a volunteer basis: 100% of your contribution goes to service projects.

column1: Boston2point62: An opportunity for everyday people to have All the Glory with 1/10th the Pain.
The Real Winners: Boston’s Deserving Young People
No matter who crosses the finish line first on race day, the true winners are the boys and girls whose lives are enriched through Downtown Boston Rotary Club's community service projects.
We cooperate with Sole Train, Germaine-Lawrence and Junior Achievement. Please see http://www.commonmansmarathon.com/cmm-beneficiaries.html for more about these terrific organizations.

With your help, we can increase our involvement with these folks, start a Downtown Boston Interact club (ages 14-18), do joint community service projects with neighboring Rotary Clubs, and build new relationships from scratch to last.
What You Can Do
REGISTER TO RUN - $30 for adults, $20 for ages 10-16, under 10 free. Please register online at http://www.commonmansmarathon.com.
VOLUNTEER - We need bag-checkers and folks to hand out numbers before the race. We need lots of course marshals during the race. We need finish-line timers at the end of the race.
SPONSOR - Spread your word! We have Basic ($100) through Platinum ($2000) levels of sponsorship. Sign up at:http://www.commonmansmarathon.com/cmm-sponsors.html
<div>
<h3 style=""font-size: 1.17em
<div>
REGISTER A LOCAL TO RUN - See the perks. Or register a friend online at http://www.commonmansmarathon.com
GET THE WORD OUT - Please use the IndieGoGo share tools.
VISIT A ROTARY CLUB - Every club has its own personality. Visitors are welcome!
Common Man's Marathon's anything-but-common 2012 sponsors include:
Against the Wind - Vitacoco - Boloco - Boston Breakers - Boston Business Journal - Cakeology - CrossFit Boston - Equinox - Goodwin Proctor - ING - NuBound - Roaste.com - Rotary International
Rotary's Four-Way Test
Of the things we think, say or do
1. Is it the TRUTH?
2. Is it FAIR to all concerned?
3. Will it build GOODWILL and BETTER RELATIONSHIPS?
4. Will it be BENEFICIAL to all concerned?

Isn't it Crazy...
We think it’s crazy that in this day and age, millions of people in poor countries suffer from debilitating medical conditions that can be treated with a simple surgery.

So we teamed up to do something about it. Samahope, a website we’re building, lets you change a person's life for just a few dollars by funding his or her procedure. We focus on surgeries that are low cost, have a high rate of success, and create major life impact for the patient, including treatment for burns, cleft palate, and obstetric fistula. You can learn all about the procedures we fund here.
How it Works

1. We choose great partners
We vet local clinics and hospitals in poor communities with a track record of excellent care using a combination of interviews, analysis of the clinic’s financial information, publicly available reviews on leading charity watchdog sites, and on-site visits.

2. Users fund real patients
Approved partners post profiles of real patients who have recently received or are awaiting a surgery. Visitors to Samahope choose patients they’d like to fund and donate via PayPal or credit card. Thanks to the support of a few early donors and our “tip jar” system, 100% of users’ donations go to the surgical partner for conducting the procedure.

Each month, we collect donations for each patient and send them to the partner performing the surgery. Our partners posts updates on a regular basis to allow donors to track the progress of the surgeries they have funded.

3. We ensure donors’ money is well spent
We conduct frequent site and patient audits using a combination of staff and volunteer field visits to guarantee all information on the site is accurate, to the best of our knowledge. With fewer than 1,000 surgeries on Samahope, we are able to audit 10% or more of all surgeries. As the site scales, we will adjust our audit sample size accordingly. For a list of current patient audits, please refer to Tab 2 of our transparency document.
Who We Are

We are an all-volunteer team that believes technology and direct giving can dramatically reduce suffering around the world. Leila is a social entrepreneur who founded Samasource four years ago. While in Sierra Leone last year, Leila met Dr. Maggi, a retired Texan OB/GYN who was performing 200 volunteer surgeries each year and fundraising on his own. When she returned home, she called Shawn, who had recently visited Sierra Leone and assisted Dr. Maggi with website and database work. Together, the two came up with the idea for Samahope. They soon roped in Shivani, an experienced program manager who had just quit her job at McKinsey, to help scale the site and launch it. Along the way, we convinced Jessica Jackley, co-founder of Kiva, to sign on as an advisor. To ignite the operation, an initial donation of $25,000 was provided by one of Leila’s board members to cover a portion of our startup costs.
With Your Help
We need your help to make Samahope happen. With $50,000, we plan to scale by:
<ul>
<li>
Adding new partners - we’ll hire a part-time staff member to help us interview and vet new partner organizations.
<li>
Adding 1,000 more surgeries - we’ll recruit 5 volunteers to visit partners on site to load patient profiles into the system and validate patient information with partial travel stipends.
<li>

Marketing the site widely to potential donors - we’ll retain a fantastic PR and marketing agency or contract professional at a discounted rate to spread awareness of what we do through social media, our blog, and advertising.
<li>

Working together as a team - we are currently all volunteers. We do most of our work on Skype and in Google Hangouts, but occasionally, we need to meet face-to-face. A modest travel budget would allow Shivani (who lives in NYC) to travel to California to meet up with Shawn and Leila (who live in LA and SF) several times in the next year. This would also allow us to visit other field partners.
If this campaign exceeds our wildest dreams and raises over $100,000, we’ll be able to invest in a solid team that can do so much more:
<ul>
<li>
Improving the user experience - we’ll invest more in site development to make Samahope faster and easier to use
column2: build a better email and communications system with donors (personalized updates on each patient)
column3: and build stronger donor marketing campaigns targeted to major life events (such as weddings, birthdays, and having a baby).

column1: <li>
Improving the partner interface - we can create and provide robust reporting and administrative tools for partners, making it easy for partners to share and work with Samahope.
<li>
Creating stronger profiles of patients - we'll add video profiles, add the ability to update profiles with post-surgery information, and explore better ways to connect directly with patients.
<li>
Adding 5,000 more surgeries to the site - we'll add substantially more surgeries to the site.
What You Get

We’re offering some incredible perks to friends in the Indiegogo community who support our campaign, with anything from $1 to $15,000. From ""Give Life"" pins to rad African-print caps, totes, and headbands, we’ve got you covered. We’re also offering the trip of a lifetime for donors at the $15,000 level.
The Impact

Crowdfunding has radically changed the funding landscape for startups, medical innovation, creative projects, nonprofits, and even schools. Why not share the benefits of this model with the millions of people who need medical treatment but can’t afford it, by funding their surgeries?

We’ve built a site that does exactly that. Samahope could close the gap in funding for women who can’t afford to treat painful conditions arising from giving birth, and for children who are disfigured from burns or cleft palate. With your support, Samahope could grow into a platform for funding all kinds of treatable medical problems.

Our team will make this happen. Shawn has worked as an engineer for over a decade, building websites and technology solutions for leading companies including Allstate. Shivani, a former product manager, launched and marketed successful products at Microsoft and the Grameen Foundation. Leila built Samasource, an innovative social business, into a global operation with 3,000 workers in East Africa and South Asia.
Thank You + Ways to Get Involved

We are grateful for any support you can offer to get Samahope off the ground. Giving to our campaign at any level sends a signal to your friends that you care about fixing the funding problem for medical treatment for the poor.
We invite you to help us spread our message online and offline to your friends and family. Please use Indiegogo’s helpful share tools to create a ripple effect with your gift.
More on the Team

Leila Janah is the founder of Samasource, an award-winning social business that connects people living in poverty to work via the internet. Leila is also on the Board of CARE. Early in her career, she co-founded Incentives for Global Health with Yale-based moral philosopher Dr. Thomas Pogge and helped produce a plan for incentivizing the development of new drugs for neglected diseases. Fun Fact: Leila was an anchor for a local, low-budget teen news program on a city-cable TV station in CA.

Shawn Graft spends most of his waking hours thinking of ways to
improve processes using technology. He brings his start-up mentality
to the corporate world and constantly challenges himself and others to
""Get Stuff Done!"" His approach is pragmatic but progressive. Shawn and his wife welcomed their daughter, Sloane, to their family earlier this year. Fun Fact: Shawn often goes on long cycling rides or runs to brainstorm. He and his wife raced and completed a 36 mile beach run in 2010...on sand.

Shivani Garg Patel is a former product manager, consultant turned social entrepreneur. Throughout her career, Shivani has focused on technology driven innovation across the private, public and social sectors. Her work with Samahope is inspired partly by her time in college leading a non-profit providing free medical and social services to the low-income population of Berkeley. Fun Fact: Shivani once modeled facial expressions for an english-language learning book in Japan.

Visit www.samahope.org to learn more

0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""><h2><strong><span style=""color: #e6086d

I AM THAT GIRL is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization dedicated to building community and creating healthy media that inspires girls to realize their worth. We are raising money to expand our I AM THAT GIRL : Local program, a chapter program that allows girls worldwide to join our movement, support each other, and come together to have honest conversations about things that matter. With your support, we will collectively raise $50,000 by November 30. The money will be used to create at least 10 new I AM THAT GIRL : Local chapters. Each chapter will impact the lives of countless girls.

I AM THAT GIRL : Local is a chapter program that puts into practice the beliefs that are the foundation of our organization – collaboration over competition, contribution over consumption. Chapters build support networks of community, enhance personal and professional development, and give girls the opportunity to make a difference in this world. Finally, girls will realize that we are on the same team and that we are not alone. And when that is realized… the possibilities are endless!
<h2><strong><span style=""color: #e6086d

IATG: Austin is one of the newest chapters, a small group with big hearts and an even bigger dream! We hope to raise money to help start chapters all over the world. We have all found that moving, coming to a new school or even just finding new friends can be hard on a young woman in today's society. So it is our mission to have IATG chapters in every city so that no matter where life may take us, we will always have a built in ""crew"" of ladies who are fighting to make this world a better place than when we came!
<h2><strong><span style=""color: #e6086d

Please take a look at our perks to the right! If you donate the right amount, you can score a t-shirt, a book, or a coaching session with our amazing founder, Alexis Jones. You can get involved by sharing our story with people in your life, starting your own local chapter, funding a local chapter ($5,000 annually), and being someone who cares enough to make a difference in the lives of others! All donations are tax-deductible.
Please visit www.iamthatgirl.com to learn more.

From all of us at I AM THAT GIRL, thank you.

Why I am interested in volunteering at The Rift Valley Children's Village
* The following text is my response to an application question posed by the Tanzania Children’s Fund before accepting me as a volunteer at The Rift Valley Children’s Village.

Children are extraordinary gifts. Their exceptional ability to adapt to their environment and harness genuine creativity baffles me to no end. In my personal experience, children crave growth when they're settled into a stimulating learning environment, and later on, radiate when they share what they’ve learned. I think the material taught in a classroom can be a key to unlocking endless opportunities.
More importantly, these environments that nurture education offer a safe space for people to learn and practice empathy, respect and support.

Bringing caregivers from other cultures into a classroom can provide an important mentor-pupil relationship. I believe it could introduce a thrilling dynamic of culture and support. Hopefully there could be an open forum around the exchange of culture, which is a lesson better learned firsthand.

I am a Bachelors of Fine Art graduate photography major from the University of Manitoba (class of 2011). While I am volunteering at The Rift Valley Children's Village in Tanzania I plan on taking thousands of photographs documenting my stay at RVCV and the breathtaking landscape around me.
In exchange for your support I plan on sharing my experience with you through my photography. Once I’ve edited my photos, the best images will be triaged into the following categories:
Perk Editions

1) **Limited Gold Edition**: Respective sponsor will have access to view this package before choosing one out of the best three 20x24"" high resolution images. $500 perk includes printing, mounting, framing, shipping to your door. Selected photo will be named, numbered and signed.
2) Silver &
column2: Bronze Editions: Respective sponsor will have access to all photos (excluding gold edition), and choose one from that selection.

column1: NOTE* All photographs (unless options are requested) will be sent via email, with a fixed resolution, as a digital negative, so you may print the photo at any photo lab near you. I will also send out a signed certificate of authenticity stating where &
column2: when the photograph was taken and the name of the artist.

column1: Artist's printing recommendation: from a digital negative, you can print the photos on regular paper, metallic paper or canvas AND/OR have them mounted on foam board, acrylic mount or wrapped on a wood frame at your convenience.
Print &
If you purchase a print or print with a frame, the prints will be printed on a color Chromira LED printer on luster paper and framed in a black studio frame.
Multiple Photos
If you purchase more than one photo and require shipping, please contact me at tracytomchuk@hotmail.com and a shipping charge will be recalculated.
What you can expect

I may not be able to provide an example of the prints I will bring home with me, but I can show you some of my previous work. In the Gallery tab just above the video are samples of what I do as a professional photographer.
You may also click the link following link to be redirected to the Gallery:
Where funds will be going
<ul>
• Flight: $1853
• Tourist Visa: $126
• Vaccinations: $483
• Protection against Malaria: $638
• Food and board - $130/week for 11 weeks: $1560
• Class C Residence Permit Fee: $500
• Transportation: $250
*I depart from Winnipeg, MB, Canada, on September 15th, 2012 :)
Thank you for reading about my project!

Why 15 Now?

MIT's Living Wage Project says a single adult needs at least $11.31/hr to live in Massachusetts and almost $13/hr to live in Boston. If you care for a child or a spouse, the cost nearly doubles.

What's the minimum wage in Massachusetts? $8/hr. In order to simply live, working people have to find two jobs, leave their children while working, or forgo higher education - anything to make ends meet. Right now, 11% of the state lives in poverty. In Boston, the poverty rate is a staggering  21.2%. Massachusetts doesn't have to be this way - with a living wage, we can lift each other out of poverty, feed our families, save money for school, and build a civil society that America deserves.

15 Now is a national movement organized by working people to fix issues that affect us. We can't live off of $8/hr, we need a living wage of $15/hr. Thanks to hundreds of volunteers, 15 Now was able to push and win $15 in Seattle. Now we're looking to do the same in Massachusetts!

(Don't live in Massachusetts? See our sister campaign in Philly or our national campaign!)

What Is 15 Now Doing?

15 Now is running a non-binding public policy question (PPQ) in the state of Massachusetts, recommending that state representatives vote in favor of a $15/hr minimum wage. If we secure enough signatures in a state representative district and the Attorney General approves of the PPQ, then the PPQ will appear on the ballot in that state representative district during statewide elections on November 4th.
column2: >We're campaigning in the following cities and neighborhoods:

column1: • Dorchester
• East Boston
• Jamaica Plain
• West Roxbury
• Lowell
• Worcester
This campaign won't happen without funding.
column2: >15 Now spent almost $150,000 in Seattle during its campaign, and we estimate that we need another $150,000 to continue the campaign nationwide. We're looking to raise a portion of that in Massachusetts. A small donation can mean a lot in this fight.
column3: > For example, $15 will buy us 30 picket signs. $50 will buy us a table for canvassing.
column8:
>What Happens If We Win?

15 Now won a $15/hr minimum wage in Seattle that will transfer $3 billion in wealth from corporations to ordinary workers. That's $20,000 given to working people for every $1 donation!

Seattle is not alone. San Francisco is likely to follow, and in Chicago a $15/hr question on the ballot won 87% of the vote. That these initiatives are independent of 15 Now only speaks to the strength of the $15 movement. We support our brothers and sisters who fight for a living wage, and each victory will inspire working people to start $15 movements in their own cities.

In Massachusetts, 15 Now is looking to secure a ballot victory similar to that of Chicago. If a majority of voters support the non-binding PPQ, it will be clear that there is popular demand for $15/hr. Our state representatives will be pressured to address the issue, much like how Chicago's mayor was pressured to start a minimum wage committee. We can take the fight for $15/hr forward to victory.

Risks &
column9:
Challenges

We are currently collecting signatures for the non-binding PPQ. There's the risk that after the minimum wage question gets on the ballot, it loses the vote. That's where your donations will make a difference, we need the funding to mobilize ordinary people around the issue and dispel right-wing myths that increasing the minimum wage hurts workers.

Also, we'd like to make clear that we're going after a non-binding PPQ, not a binding one. That means if we win the question, the $15/hr minimum wage will be a advisory suggestion to legislators, not something that gets written into law. We would love to do a binding ballot question, but that takes almost 100,000 signatures and requires much greater resources than what we currently field. If we succeed with the non-binding PPQ, we'll be in a much better position to pursue a binding ballot question.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    While money is crucial, we're not some shadowy SuperPAC that can win off of money alone. 15 Now was carried forward in Seattle by the thousands who marched on the streets with us. Anyone is welcome to join and fight for $15/hr. Don't worry if you've never been politically active before - for most of us, 15 Now is the first political action group we've ever been in. We're just normal working people fed up with post-recession economy.

    If you have the time, please join our events! We post our events calendar on Facebook here:

    https://www.facebook.com/15NowNewEngland

    Also, if you want to be informed on a regular basis, shoot an email to

    15NowNewEngland@gmail.com

One day while I was sitting at a computer in the local library, endlessly sending out resume after resume
column2: I heard an interview on one of our local radio stations. It was an interview with the director of a network of soup kitchens, shelters, and a battered woman's home. Although, it wasn't really an interview, it was an actual plea, begging, a cry out for help. Supplies were drastically low, and demand was on a constant rise. I had already been volunteering my time at an associated kitchen, and not working, I couldn't afford to make any monetary donations. Yet, I knew there was something more I could do. There was an idea floating around in my mind, but it had yet to take shape.

column1: One day while I was out for a walk, the idea in my head finally began to take shape. If there weren't jobs out there in the open market, what if I created my own? I could combine my 2 biggest passions (food and fundraising) and turn them into a job. For a minimal amount of money, I would be able to provide people with quality, unique products, while at the same time creating a job for someone and giving them an opportunity to get back into the  workforce.

At first I asked family and friends. They all agreed it was a great idea, unfortunately due to their own personal financial situations were unable to make an investment. Then a friend of mine turned me on to Indiegogo. So here I am. Relying on the kindness of strangers to help me, to be able to help others, An attempt to make one or more individuals life better while at the same time providing resources to homes and shelters that are in such a desperate need.
Thank you for your time.

Best Regards
Peter Pizzati
(aspiring entrepeneur and good samaritan)

Short Summary

Hi. My name is Camellia and I would like to combine my life's passion--giving--with a a sustainable money-making idea. The Missions Depot is an entrepreneurial effort, a thrift store in which the proceeds raised will go to benefit relief and missions efforts locally, nationally and abroad.

For more than 20 years I have been involved in, helped to fund and even initiated all kinds of relief and missions-minded efforts from projects involving jails, nursing homes, and hospitals to shelters and orphanages. I have both traveled the globe and worked diligently wherever my hands could find to minister and be a blessing here in the United States. Now I would like to open a ""station"" where goods are bought, sold, traded, and consigned so that various projects can continue to be funded throughout the world!

The Missions Depot will always demonstrate that the more you give the more you receive. We will accept gently used donations of all sorts of items, then resell them at unbeatable prices. Customers leave with the amazing feeling of purchasing something valuable for little money, PLUS the thrill of knowing that the bulk of their dollar is going to help people across the globe.
<h3>What We Need &amp
Here's the downlow on what we need:
<ul>
• $150,000 for the purchase of the property which houses the retail store, offices, 3 apartments, a storage and processing building, an outbuilding. The land equals 3 ajoined lots.
• Ann, the current owner, says that the building will require about $10K in plumbing updates. I also estimate another 20K in general repairs, remodeling, and proper lighting.
• We need 7K for material to construct shelving, racks and counters to sell our goods. Think: barrels, bins, baskets, and buckets! We want the store to have that old-timey depot feel.

• We need 25K to remodle and renovate the two apartments that are not yet being inhabited. Why? If we can rent these out, it will not only cover annual property taxes, but during slow seasons in sales this will guarantee that the
• Missions Depot will never have to close its doors for lack of funds.
Here's what you get:
<ul>

• Beyond the thrill of knowing that you have made the world a little better place for someone and touched lives across the globe, you will also recieve very personalized thanks. We have prepared some heartfelt ways of saying ""thank you for helping us reach out to others.""

• We've got everything from personalized thank you letters to trinkets, to a wall of fame and even some old-fashioned handmade crafts so that you know that your generosity is truly appreciated. Be sure to check out the rest of the page to see the incentives!
The Impact
I have been incredibly blessed to be found missions and relief efforts for many years, organizing community efforts like Dinner for a Dollar
column3: and humanitarian efforts like Blankets for Babiesin which crochets mini-blankets were donated to NICU's in various cities. Besides that I have been honored to work with missionaries on a number of countries and even have my own workd in Mexico, Honduras, and the Philippines.

column1: Having said that I want to be clear that proceeds raised from the Missions Depot will NEVER be limited to helping people in one particular country.  Donors, sponsors, and patrons are ALWAYS invited and encouraged to keep us abreast of where goods and funds are most needed in the world at any given time. That way we can have the greatest impact possible at home and abroad.
<div>
Other Ways You Can Help
Some of you just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:
<ul>
• PLEASE help me get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
• PLEASE use the Indiegogo share tools!Like on FB, tweet and retweet on twitter. With your help we can go global.

Even if all the $250 is not raised, we will STILL CONTINUE to attempt to get this idea off the ground. Even with $150 we can at the very least purchase theh property and put off repairs until later. THANK YOU SO MUCH!!!!!!!

What's SmartGardener?
SmartGardener makes it easy for anyone to plan, plant, harvest and share food grown from their home or community gardens. We launched last May with one goal:
column2: >Help home gardeners simply grow great food. We have over
column3: >10,000 users</font> and over <font size=""4""><span style=""font-weight: bold
column4: >10,000 gardens now made by people seeking to start or improve their food gardens and their lives.
column5:
>So why are we here on Indiegogo?

Many of us want to grow our own clean, healthy, great tasting food. But it can be overwhelming, intimidating and time consuming to start and manage a garden. We want to help those people get started and be successful. Using technology in smart ways, we make this easier, and much more personalized, based on your location, household size, tastes, and growing conditions. We even send you reminders of exactly what you need to do each week.


The development of this product has been self-funded for the last two years in order to provide a really simple engaging solution to more people who want to be growing great food.

How will we use the money we raise?
Smart Gardener is a free personalized service that home gardeners are already using, but we'd like to grow the community. Our goal of $10,000 will pay for additional

column1: features that help our community connect, share and benefit from each
others' efforts. </font>

1) An online community MarketPlace so you can share or trade your garden's bounty with others locally

2) A means for gardeners with similar growing conditions to easily connect with each other to share tips and advice
Our $10,000 goal will let us provide
column2: >more community support for home gardeners everywhere</font>.<font size=""4"" style=""font-weight: bold
column3: > That's why we're reaching out through Indiegogo to friends and fans who believe, like we do, that home food gardening is good for our taste-buds, our health, our family, our community, our pocketbooks ...and our future.

column1: We greatly appreciate your help and support! Please spread the word by sharing our project through email, Twitter or any of your social networks.
Thanks! ~ Kristee Rosendahl, Brittany Rowles &
","What's SmartGardener?

SmartGardener makes it easy for anyone to plan, plant, harvest and share food grown from their home or community gardens. We launched last May with one goal: Help home gardeners simply grow great food. We have over 10,000 users and over 10,000 gardens now made by people seeking to start or improve their food gardens and their lives. So why are we here on Indiegogo? Many of us want to grow our own clean, healthy, great tasting food. But it can be overwhelming, intimidating and time consuming to start and manage a garden. We want to help those people get started and be successful. Using technology in smart ways, we make this easier, and much more personalized, based on your location, household size, tastes, and growing conditions. We even send you reminders of exactly what you need to do each week.The development of this product has been self-funded for the last two years in order to provide a really simple engaging solution to more people who want to be growing great food.How will we use the money we raise?Smart Gardener is a free personalized service that home gardeners are already using, but we'd like to grow the community. Our goal of $10,000 will pay for additional
features that help our community connect, share and benefit from each
others' efforts.

1) An online community MarketPlace so you can share or trade your garden's bounty with others locally2) A means for gardeners with similar growing conditions to easily connect with each other to share tips and advice

Our $10,000 goal will let us provide more community support for home gardeners everywhere. That's why we're reaching out through Indiegogo to friends and fans who believe, like we do, that home food gardening is good for our taste-buds, our health, our family, our community, our pocketbooks ...and our future.
We greatly appreciate your help and support! Please spread the word by sharing our project through email, Twitter or any of your social networks.
Thanks! ~ Kristee Rosendahl, Brittany Rowles & Frank Tozer",0.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Healdsburg, CA, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/smartgardener-simply-grow-great-food/pica

Help me nake my dream true. To bring ""Meet Me There Events"" social activities to life full time. $5 or $10 is all will take to get it started. Here's my story
Short Summary

Hi, I'm Adrian, I moved from New York to S. Florida three years ago. As a hobby and a way to make new friends, I started running unique and creative group events in S. Florida to get out of the bored rut. After a while it took on a life of its own. Once I started our first few events and saw how much fun it was bringing strangers together, it fueled my obsession of doing this on a much broader scale. It brings me great joy when members rave about how much fun they had, or how they met a new friend at one of our events. This funding will help me start a massive marketing campain. Thus allowing for many new members in your area and expanding into several new cities. Look for us in your city soon.
You can see pictures and types of events at www.MeetMeThereEvents.com

Before moving I owned an event planning business in NYC for over 18 years. Having worked for clients who where planning such important private events, I became highly skilled in being detailed oriented, diligent, resourceful and creative. After exiting the private party world, I went on to become a Licensed Realtor for RE/MAX. But, they say, ""Do what you love and you'll love what you do"". Well, I love running this group and want to do it full time. I've never had so much fun in my life creating fun for other people.

Your contributions are actually not for me. They are for the members. As they are the recipients of this service. Life is filled with work, families, stress, bills and plenty of adult seriousness. Members need our group as an outlet to express their inner kid and to have more laughter and enjoyment in their lives. Because we do these as group events, they benefit by meeting many new friends that they wouldn't normally meet in their daily lives.
What We Need &

$25,000 is what it would take to get it started. I have been out of pocket for all costs associated with running this group. However, I have devised a very affordable member fee that helps in the cost of running the group. It's extremely affordable with no pressure to participate if they can't. Unlike a similar group who charges over 100 times what we do. Plus, they limit the membership to a year. Once our members pay a onetime fee, they are members for life.

A small portion would be for legal fees. Incorporation fees, liability agreement, a few web page enhancements etc.. The Majority, approximately $20,000, would be used to run radio spots for approximately 8 - 10 months consistently. It would not be spent all at once. Between, $1,500 and $2,000 a month would be spent on this marketing. This would allow for consistency and more importantly, letting me see the conversion rate after 90 days. The marketing will drve traffic to our web site and increase membership.
If the goal is not met, I will still use the funds in the same manner and begin marketing. I will work hard as continuing to raise the balance from angels and out of pocket myself.
One perk offered to any contributor would be a complimentary membership.
The Impact

Not only do we plan events for our members but, we post information about charities, community events and encourage them to get involved. From time to time we actually plan an outing that brings our members to a charity event such as when we did the ""Walk for MS"", or ""beach cleanup"". Part of my plan is to be able to grow the membership and have recurring community events that we can actively participate in on a regular basis. Part of our blog is dedicated to allowing members to post information about charitable events or non profits. This gives them an outlet to share with other members. My goal is to be a bigger part of the community.

My success is the fact that I have planned over 200 events and brought many new friendships to life. Your contribution will allow people who are looking for more social interaction, the ability to do so more frequently without costing and arm and a leg. Plainly put, I am a people person. I work at hard at fulfilling my members needs and wants and put them first before mine. I have dozens of unsolicited testimonials from members who have said such great things about how I planned and executed our events.

On September 16th, 2012, a 14-year-old boy named Dustun Dalton died after falling forty feet off of a bluff behind his house. This tragic accident struck our small farming community and we grieve for this beautiful, sweet boy who had to leave us much too soon. Dustun was a very loving, caring young boy who embraced life and loved those around him. He lived in the small town of Blaine, Tennessee with his aunt and uncle, John and Sandy Bernard who raised him as a son, and his two sisters as well as three cousins who loved him like a brother.

Sadly, tragedies like these incur many expenses. No one expects something like this to happen to someone so young, and we want to extend our sympathies and give them the help that Dustun and they deserve. Proceeds will go to the family to cover funeral expenses and additional expenses incurred due to the accident. This fundraiser would help to ease the burdens on a grieving family.

Dustun was a very active member of his church and their youth group. He lived to make those around him smile and our community aches for him and for his family. Dustun’s presence in this world made it a better place and it is dimmer for him having gone so soon.
Dustun was my baby sister's boyfriend and he means a lot to our family. He made her the happiest girl on earth and we want to offer his family all of the support and comfort that they deserve.
Any contribution at all would be greatly appreciated. Please share this page with your friends and family on facebook, twitter, tumblr, anywhere you can!

Below we have listed Dustun’s obituary and a news article on the tragedy. Any questions may be directed to sarahkaitlinparker@gmail.com.

What’s this all about?
We were inspired to do this project because staying local is so important to retaining the culture of our communities.  Some of the benefits of having local mom &
<ul>
<li>
They employ more people than chains
<li>
Keep twice as much of the money in the local area
• Nearby home value increases 50% faster
Not to mention they create a more vibrant community to live in.  Yet compared to 10 years ago, there are 300,000 fewer mom &
column2: pop businesses in America (U.S. Census Data).

column1: We seek to use mobile technology to help the remaining 1.2 million of these businesses stay competitive.  84% of small businesses with a mobile presence report increased sales...yet only 14% maintain a mobile presence.
That’s why we created Domino Street especially for mom &
column2: pop establishments - to promote themselves in an easy time-efficient way while simultaneously providing locals with a rich, experiential way to stay in touch with their neighborhood.  Domino Street quickly answers, ""What's happening right now?"" or ""What's going-on this weekend?""

column1: To make it even more powerful and easy for mom &
column2: pop businesses, we’ve created special tools (i.e. the Domino Merchant App) which allows them to upload content directly to Domino Street, their Facebook page, and their Twitter stream...all in a matter of seconds using their smartphone.

column1: If you’re a Small Business Owner: We’d LOVE to hear from you! Please sign-up on our website so we can add your business when we roll-out Domino Street and the Domino Merchant App to your neighborhood.
The Domino Street App:
We want to create something to allow people to experience what’s going on around them.  We know from the success of photo sharing apps, that rich imagery is a powerful way to accomplish this.

We aim to build a super easy, almost playful way to browse what’s new, relevant, and fresh in your neighborhood.  We’re not a deals app, we’re not an events app, nor are we a curated guide.   We are simply an app that connects you to what’s happening in your neighborhood.
What’s in the app?
<ul>
<li>
Eat + Drink: Chalkboard specials, happy hours, new cocktails
<li>
Shop: New Merchandise, Current Sales, promote In-store events
<li>
Culture: Event based - Music concerts, Art openings, Movie Night, Food Festival, etc.
Snap Deal: Users take a picture of an item &
column2: post to Facebook/Twitter = unlock existing eCoupon

column1: How we’ll complete our project:
- Domino has already created mobile experiences for events such as
column3: Drink, The Vintage Crawl, and the Brooklyn Flea. We are a team of 10 people - designers, technologists, and people with passion around local events, arts, and fashion.

column1: - We have submitted a prototype of Domino Street to the App Store which we are planning to test in our local neighborhood of Williamsburg starting Sept 12th. Where we need help is to make this available to all neighborhoods. To do that, we have to rework our technology somewhat. This includes a redesign of the front end to allow users to hop between neighborhoods. We need to also build an android version of the app, as well as add a few features that did not make it into the prototype.  We also need to build a scalable backend that can support a large number of users and small businesses using the app. Finally we will need to pay for promotional materials and on-the-ground forces.

We estimate this will cost about $30k (we raise $28k on hitting a $35k goal), but could use a bit more.  We expect the upgrades and expansion to take about 4-6 weeks once we are funded enough to begin work.
Where will the money go?
<ul>
• 68% Tech / UX development ($23,800)
<ul>
<li dir=""ltr""><span>Make prototype stable &amp
column2: usable in any neighborhood in U.S.

column1: • Create Android versions for Domino Street and Merchant App
• Improve backend to support more features and handle greater user load
• Add additional nav features (sorting/search/vendor bookmarks)
• Create additional filters for merchants to use
• Create Domino Street plugin for local websites
• Build Merchant web portal
• Create feed of 3rd party music events directly into app
• Upgrade maps
• Maintain Servers for 1 year
<li>15% Outreach &amp
<ul>
• Printing of promo materials
• Dedicated on-the-ground merchant outreach
• Hire temp personnel for distribution
• 10% Rewards ($3,500)
• 7% Indiegogo / processing fees ($2,450)

Any additional funds raised beyond our target will go into enhancements and features that we would like to include such as greater mobile support for local events (alerts, event maps, and video capability) as well as increasing the speed at which we can roll out to new neighborhoods.
Rewards

<div>

$100 Reward - Poster of Williamsburg, Brooklyn

Meet Our Crew:

Ryan Allbaugh : Technology
Ryan currently works as the Chief Information Officer at one of the largest privately held commercial real estate and property management companies in the southeast US where he is responsible for defining the strategic technology initiatives as they relate to the company and smart building technology.  He is responsible for managing all of the company's technology projects, IT operations and help desk teams.  With over 15 years of technology experience, Ryan sits on numerous industry recognized conference advisory boards including Realcomm, IBConn as well as being a member of the Envision Charlotte Model Programs steering committee.
<div>

Rohit Aggarwal : Technology
Rohit has over 10 years of experience in web development. He has specialties inMobile Web, HTML, CSS, JavaScript/ jQuery, PHP (MVC Frameworks), MySQL. He has worked on behalf of clients including Duncan Hines, CHANEL, Ubisoft, Zoo York, IMG Media, Wrigley, and Pfizer. He was awarded the most valuable peer while at Cegedim Dendrite.
<div>

Caroline Szeto Dahlmanns : Creative/Design
Caroline owns and runs Caroline Design – a branding and design studio. Caroline has over 15 years experience in brand identity, visual design, and user experience design. She’s worked with innovative brands including Equinox Fitness, LUCKYRICE, Morgan Stanley, Bank of America &
<div>

Peter Koo : Technology
Currently a developer at Citadel Investment, Peter develops enterprise scalable solutions. His tenure includes JP Morgan Chase, Credit Suisse First Boston, and Marsh &
<div>

Vasili Gavre : Music Relations
Vasili is a music strategist and executive producer. He’s worked with Cirque du Soleil, bands such as the Beastie Boys, Moby, and many others. As an advertiser, he has helped brands such as Budweiser, Target, and Victoria’s Secret leverage music content to build ad campaigns. He has been interviewed by Billboard &
column2: Spin, and is a frequent speaker at SXSW &amp

column1: <div>
Kathryn Irby : PR &
column2:
Merchant Relations
As the fashion features associate for LUCKY magazine, she curated the national magazine’s influential back page and shopping guides. Served as Gap inc.’s fashion forecastor for Gap Women’s apparel &
column3: accessories collections. She has also created her own brand - The Brooklyn Vintage Crawl.

column1: <div>

Kate Menard : Community Relations
Katie has been working in community based social service and educational settings for over 10 years. Katie received an M.S.W. with a focus in Group Work from the Hunter College School of Social Work.
<div>

Andrea Ivancic : Gallery Relations
Andrea has 5 years of experience as the Director of Brusso Hardware, a design industry leader specialized in hardware for cabinetry, furniture, and woodworking. Andrea has been an active member of the New York art community during this time as well. Most recently she curated an art and design tour of Williamsburg with Damsels in Design.
<div>
<div>

Eric Murray : Co-Founder
Eric has been a musician, an artist, a photographer, a designer, a programmer, and if not enough, started and ran his own company for many years.
<div>

Manoj Aggarwal : Co-Founder
Manoj has over 15 years work experience in technology, marketing, and social media. He has worked on over 50 Fortune 500 brands including Amex, Microsoft, GM, Phillips, GSK, Delta, and Time Warner - leading them to success in digital and social media and currently consults for multiple brands. His campaigns have won awards for their innovation within social media.

","What’s this all about?
We were inspired to do this project because staying local is so important to retaining the culture of our communities.  Some of the benefits of having local mom & pop businesses include...
They employ more people than chains
Keep twice as much of the money in the local area
Nearby home value increases 50% faster
Not to mention they create a more vibrant community to live in.  Yet compared to 10 years ago, there are 300,000 fewer mom & pop businesses in America (U.S. Census Data).

We seek to use mobile technology to help the remaining 1.2 million of these businesses stay competitive.  84% of small businesses with a mobile presence report increased sales...yet only 14% maintain a mobile presence.

That’s why we created Domino Street especially for mom & pop establishments - to promote themselves in an easy time-efficient way while simultaneously providing locals with a rich, experiential way to stay in touch with their neighborhood.  Domino Street quickly answers, ""What's happening right now?"" or ""What's going-on this weekend?""

To make it even more powerful and easy for mom & pop businesses, we’ve created special tools (i.e. the Domino Merchant App) which allows them to upload content directly to Domino Street, their Facebook page, and their Twitter stream...all in a matter of seconds using their smartphone.

If you’re a Small Business Owner: We’d LOVE to hear from you! Please sign-up on our website so we can add your business when we roll-out Domino Street and the Domino Merchant App to your neighborhood.
The Domino Street App:
We want to create something to allow people to experience what’s going on around them.  We know from the success of photo sharing apps, that rich imagery is a powerful way to accomplish this.

We aim to build a super easy, almost playful way to browse what’s new, relevant, and fresh in your neighborhood.  We’re not a deals app, we’re not an events app, nor are we a curated guide.   We are simply an app that connects you to what’s happening in your neighborhood.

How we’ll complete our project:

- Domino has already created mobile experiences for events such as Shop, Drop & Drink, The Vintage Crawl, and the Brooklyn Flea. We are a team of 10 people - designers, technologists, and people with passion around local events, arts, and fashion.

- We have submitted a prototype of Domino Street to the App Store which we are planning to test in our local neighborhood of Williamsburg starting Sept 12th. We estimate this will cost about $30k (we raise $28k on hitting a $35k goal), but could use a bit more.  We expect the upgrades and expansion to take about 4-6 weeks once we are funded enough to begin work.

Hire temp personnel for distribution

Any additional funds raised beyond our target will go into enhancements and features that we would like to include such as greater mobile support for local events (alerts, event maps, and video capability) as well as increasing the speed at which we can roll out to new neighborhoods.

As an advertiser, he has helped brands such as Budweiser, Target, and Victoria’s Secret leverage music content to build ad campaigns. He has been interviewed by Billboard & Spin, and is a frequent speaker at SXSW & CMJ.

Kathryn Irby : PR & Merchant RelationsAs the fashion features associate for LUCKY magazine, she curated the national magazine’s influential back page and shopping guides. Served as Gap inc.’s fashion forecastor for Gap Women’s apparel & accessories collections. She has also created her own brand - The Brooklyn Vintage Crawl.

Kate Menard : Community RelationsKatie has been working in community based social service and educational settings for over 10 years. Katie received an M.S.W. with a focus in Group Work from the Hunter College School of Social Work.

Andrea Ivancic : Gallery RelationsAndrea has 5 years of experience as the Director of Brusso Hardware, a design industry leader specialized in hardware for cabinetry, furniture, and woodworking. Andrea has been an active member of the New York art community during this time as well. Most recently she curated an art and design tour of Williamsburg with Damsels in Design.
Eric Murray : Co-FounderEric has been a musician, an artist, a photographer, a designer, a programmer, and if not enough, started and ran his own company for many years.

Manoj Aggarwal : Co-FounderManoj has over 15 years work experience in technology, marketing, and social media. He has worked on over 50 Fortune 500 brands including Amex, Microsoft, GM, Phillips, GSK, Delta, and Time Warner - leading them to success in digital and social media and currently consults for multiple brands. His campaigns have won awards for their innovation within social media.
Check out our website for more information:http://dominostreetapp.com/",16.0,0,"1 Campaign

Lines of Designs--Recharge!

Lines of Designs is a women's retail store with an interesting twist!  Besides selling name brand ready to wear, Lines of Designs is also the name on the label for locally designed and produced garments, sizes 0-26.  I'm Luise Langheinrich, owner of Lines of Designs, and I have been designing commercially for 17 years with production kept local.  The ""twist"" is if you come in, try on one of my designs and it doesn't quite fit, I tweak the pattern to fit your body!  I love what I do and it's my customers that have kept the retail side in business and growing for the last 9 years.

But now I need your help.  Many of you know that the building I lease space in has been undergoing a facade renovation.  The building was built in 1910 and originally had transom windows above the storefront, which are now filled with plywood.  This is the first major project under The Dalles Main Street Organization in partnership with The City of The Dalles.  Hopefully other businesses and building owners won't be scared off by what I have been through.

The project started in May, 2017 and was slated to last 2 weeks.  Three months later, due to unexpected discoveries, I have been shut down 3 times and we are in our 3rd engineering redesign.  I will be shut down again as this renovation continues in August.  My revenue stream has been severely interrupted and I need your financial help so that I may bring in my fall inventory and continue with my designs.
Business Recharge
I am asking for $18,000 to recharge my business:  bring in my fall inventory and continue my designs.  Help me get there and receive some great perks in return for your support!
The breakdown of the $18,000 recharge budget is as follows:
<ul>
• $8500 for in-store fall inventory that has been pre-ordered last spring
<li>$3600 for fabric &amp
• $3200 for labor to sew up the fabric (160 hours worth)
• $1400 fees for Indiegogo (it costs money to raise money)
• $1000 cost of perks for this campaign
• $300 new vinyl signage for store windows since old ones will be taken out

Lines of Designs is a proven business with a reputation for excellent service, great fitting designs, and fun workshops.  The business is run in a socially and environmentally responsible manner.  Please  join me in keeping Lines of Designs a thriving fun place for those wanting a flattering fit that won't go out of style.
Other Ways You Can Help
I would love your help in getting the word out:  your facebook friends, book clubs, social groups, service groups, co-workers, ...  Every little bit helps!

I started a campaign in May 2013, which is Lupus Awareness Month.
My good friend Heidi is living with Lupus, a chronic, autoimmune disease that can damage any part of the body.
Our goal for this round is $1000, but we'd love to raise more for Heidi to get her everything she needs listed below.
<div class=""js-fundpage__fund-desc-outer"" style=""height: auto
<div class=""js-fundpage__fund-desc-inner"">
<h3 style=""margin-bottom: 23px

column3: >About Heidi, she's a single mother of three awesome children, one who is going to college in the fall. Her youngest son has recently started to show symptoms of Lupus, so she has many challenges to face and not much financial support.

>She's a great actress and friend. I first met Heidi when I was looking for an actress in the bay area for a short I was directing. We've been friends ever since. Heidi has been through a lot: homelessness, passing of her mother (who also suffered from lupus), pain, and fear. Through it all, she is one of the strongest women I know. See her blog for more details about her struggles.
>Check out the shorts she's starred in on my youtube page: www.youtube.com/carenow78

Update from July 8:

Heidi was denied coverage again and told that she will receive a medical bill of 34K to pay back the governent. What is the country coming to? If the government won't help our people, we need to step up and help while we can. - See more at: http://www.youcaring.com/other/i-m-going-hairle...
Update from July 8:
Heidi was denied coverage again and told that she will receive a medical bill
of 34K to which she needs to pay back the government.
Updates from Heidi June 20:

column3: >Heidi was dropped from SSD after an incomplete medical review. Right now, she is in appeals awaiting a decision. If they still come back and determine she's no longer disabled under the eyes of the government, she will lose her income, her Medicare, AND have to pay back the money she's received while in appeals.

column1: <h3 style=""margin-bottom: 23px

column3: >Heidi was diagnosed with white Lupus plaques throughout her frontal lobe and her disease is progressing rapidly. She was told that she must start Imuran treatment immediately and that she will be starting full blown Cytoxin/Rituxin chemotherapy infusion within six to eight weeks time. This treatment will cause her to be very weak, needing a scooter to get around.

>
You also have an option to give on the youcaring campaign page: http://www.youcaring.com/other/i-m-going-hairless-for-heidi/70017

column1: ","I started a campaign in May 2013, which is Lupus Awareness Month.
My good friend Heidi is living with Lupus, a chronic, autoimmune disease that can damage any part of the body.
Our goal for this round is $1000, but we'd love to raise more for Heidi to get her everything she needs listed below.
About Heidi:

About Heidi, she's a single mother of three awesome children, one who is going to college in the fall. Her youngest son has recently started to show symptoms of Lupus, so she has many challenges to face and not much financial support.

She's a great actress and friend. I first met Heidi when I was looking for an actress in the bay area for a short I was directing. We've been friends ever since. Heidi has been through a lot: homelessness, passing of her mother (who also suffered from lupus), pain, and fear. Through it all, she is one of the strongest women I know. See her blog for more details about her struggles.
http://lupuslyfe.blogspot.com/
Check out the shorts she's starred in on my youtube page: www.youtube.com/carenow78
Film titles:
Can you help me?
Coffee with Nancy
Who Me?
Fight 4 Life
Please see the following Web site for more details about Lupus: http://cruelmystery.org/
The breakdown of the spending will be as such:
Scooter for Heidi (est. $4000) – I’m trying to get a discountUpdate: I found one for $2000, and we have $800 so far http://www.progressmobility.com/ew-36.html
Car repairs so Heidi can hitch the scooter to her van (est. $1300) – I’m also trying to get a discount on this.
Wig making (est. $700) – Discounted. Originally $1500 to get wig made with hair.
Additional funds will go to Heidi’s medical expenses until her repeal goes through.
Making a short documentary
I will be making a documentary about this campaign and giving my hair away to help a local child suffering from alopecia or cancer.

Update from July 8:Heidi was denied coverage again and told that she will receive a medical bill of 34K to pay back the governent. What is the country coming to? If the government won't help our people, we need to step up and help while we can. - See more at: http://www.youcaring.com/other/i-m-going-hairle...
